What you have to understand is that this whole notion of open information has always been there. Since Benjamin Franklin's lending library.

If we lived in a world with Free Software, computers would behave and be the way people think they should. Yeah, there will be cameras, but those cameras would be in local control and only reported to the feds if the owner decides to (or if there's a warrant involved). People would no longer be reported to the authorities for mundane actions like buying a bottle of water. You will no longer need to keep up with whatever the current political trend is to show your support and not get flagged. Like buying the wrong brand of water because some CEO said something racist when he was drunk.

All these associations, and the counter-intelligence between the common man and their governments just doent need to be there; and it's causing serious issues left and right.

Power to the people creates a sane and just world

>Free Software allows you to choose what gets sent and when.
No it doesn't when it's a service on someone elses computer and you are just interacting with a front end.

>Keeping everything open would also allow people (like restaurants) to offer web-based services for people.
For websites it's very easy to spin one up for a restaurant, you can just download a template and change the names. You can already do that, and it doesn't help you.
For success you need to get that restaurant page highly ranked on centrally controlled services like google, or no one will see it. The same goes for an online order system, you can download one and spin it up, but you won't get customers because they all use SERVICES like ubereats. The software for ubereats isn't really valuable at all. What is valuable is the brand name, the domain, how highly its ranked on services, and all the connected customers and resturants.

>the opposite effect would happen in terms of competition; everybody would be on the same footing and compete more.
No, there would be no option for competition, because the only advantage a small competitor can possibly have over the big ones is special software. Once that is gone, there is no possible advantage.

>GNU affero is a good faith license, but we all know monopolies and corporations are the enemy

last_replies.com:
Read Kali Linux documentation to get a sense what kind of attacks there are.
Do HackTheBox/CTFs to get some kind of sense what happens when people get le pwned (and for street cred).
Install and attack those ready-made vulnerable Windows environments to get a more realistic view.
Also look up into SIEMs/log collectors and rules related to them to see what's the blue team side of things (where most jobs are). Maybe install a SIEM to a vulnerable environment and when attacking it try to see if you can see your actions in the SIEM and then tuning stuff that you can actually detect your own attack from the SIEM.
Joining some local cybersecurity community/meetup is probably best way to get new info and network for jobs.

com:
I'm on GNOME and I'm undecided on these two file explorers. Dolphin technically is a far more robust file window, but Nautilus has far more options in it's dropdown menu + is required for some extensions on GNOME (like desktop extensions).

I'd rather not have two file explorers on the same PC since that's bloat. Can anyone help me reach a decision on this? Should I use GNOME's built in file manager?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90214426
Why? Do you have an 8GB hard drive and 2GBs of RAM? If yes, then use Gnome's. Dolphin would have to load all the QT dependencies every time you run it and you'd have only a few applications that would be able to share its memory usage. (but really what's like 70MiB of memory usage?)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90214480
No it's because Dolphin looks ugly with GNOME because of GTK and it doesn't interact with GNOME the same way it does with KDE (for instance there's no "set as wallpaper" option immediately on the dropdown menu so you have to open image viewer).
I feel like Nautilus is a lot more convenient for GNOME, but it has a lot of problems Dolphin fixes.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90214426
Dolphin is a million times better than Nautilus, but I would strongly suggest not to install it on GNOME. Have you ever looked into Nemo? It' s the default file manager for the Cinnamon DE and it's much more competent than Nautilus while not requiring thousands of KDE dependencies which could break your system at the first update.

com:
Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license.

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, weather, etc)
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with basic system apps.
>LTSC / IoT LTSC
LTSC = 5 years support, VL/KMS only
IoT LTSC = 10 years support, HWID only
Comes with Win32 system apps, no MS Store, no feature updates, security updates only.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: 
wsreset -i


>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC lasts until 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Installs a KMS server emulator, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free. As a last resort, you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice/WPS/Polaris and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>90212733
Don't erase them from your brain. They're the quickest way to solve easy tasks.
For more complex tasks they stink compared to the alternatives. So do learn a "proper" scripting language. Perl works but it's on its way out. I recommend Python: it does the job, it's wildly popular, and it's not as byzantine. (It's also either pre-installed or easy to install everywhere.)
I used to use shell for everything too, but my capabilities expanded immensely once I got the hang of Python.
Eventually you may want to learn more languages but Python is a good place to start.
(People who tell you to use C and sh/awk and nothing else are out of touch with reality. Even Kernighan uses Python.)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90213452
Every sound is made up of a pattern of sine waves decaying and potentially changing pitch at different times- think of each note as a bunch of little notes, displayed by the peaks on the spectrum analyzer.

It's normal for the second harmonic to be louder than the fundamental in bass guitars, but in the second note it does look like that first tone is comparatively louder- you could use a dynamic EQ and cut it at 69.30(?) or whatever note is playing. Obviously "use your ears" always applies but I use this for reference to be exact https://pages.mtu.edu/~suits/notefreqs.html

Note that in sampled libraries/instruments, the tuning isn't always 100% accurate, sometimes on purpose.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90213982
>Tested it on my headphones and it sounds normal
Glad you got it man.
Idk what your intentions are but in case you pursue mixing further: this is why it's important to check through multiple sources and to be familiar with what their range sounds like; a mix that "translates" is supposed to sound good everywhere, so although it may be fine, if you wanted to really be sure you would check if other songs seem to have an extra bump in that same spot on your speakers, or check to see if those bass notes sound "right" similar to your headphones on other sources as well.

Operator in ableton lets you sweep across by hertz rather than note and it's very worth doing it and taking note of where it dips, bumps, and starts to decline in the low end.

Ableton doesn't have a dynamic EQ, but if you want to learn about it there are plenty of youtube tutorials. Personally prefer Fabfilter Pro-Q3 but TDR Nova is a great plugin.

last_replies.com:
>>90212404
Assuming that by "Linux" you mean "GNU/Linux", the following two come to mind.

1) Abandon Wayland. In the 14 years of its existence, it has caused nothing but further balkanization and no real improvement over X. All that effort should be spent improving X instead
>inb4 unfixable
14 years of full time paid development are enough to unfuck any project.

2) There needs to be a standardized platform-wide, powerful and easy to use graphical toolkit. Toolkits are basically the one component that has never maintained a stable and reliable API for applications to use (at ,least before the advent of Wayland), and this is the main reason we still see so many ncurses-based programs.

As much as terminal limitations are outdated, ncurses is pretty much guaranteed to be present on every GNU/Linux system (and every Unix-like system in general), which makes it a safe bet to target for portable applications with some semblance of graphical interface. Other APIs, such as X and Linux kernel APIs themselves, have always been very stable, graphical toolkits are the only part that is to blame for the mistaken notion that GNU/Linux has no backwards compatibility, at least when compared to Windows.

sub: My (probably insane) views on the future of AI
com:
Everything in here is hypothetical. Please take everything with a grain of salt, this is purely my brain dumping onto a page while I was sleep deprived. At the bottom I included a handful of caveats to things I said. Also, I am specifically choosing to use the word "AI" over the term "Machine Learning." Current machine learning like ChatGPT is a huge step towards true AIs, but we still have a long way to go. I am in no way an expert on any of these topics and its entirely likely that everything I said is wrong.

Any time someone envisions a Utopia in fiction, where are the people who do the work to build that society? Best case scenario all the work has been replaced by robots, and worse case there ends up being some kind of indentured servitude hidden in the shadows. Obviously for a long time this has been simply fiction, but with the new buzz around ChatGPT I thought I'd share an idea I've had for a while now.

Throughout history, the large majority of problems faced by society have happened because of one thing; greed. Greed for power, greed for money, etc, etc. Assuming that in a vacuum humans wouldn't just resort back to greed, how can we prevent inequality from happening? I believe that AI and robots could be our solution.

> Abolishing Money
Lets start with monetary greed. In the current state of the world, removing currency just isn't possible. Someone needs to make the products and food we buy every day, but if there's no pay then no one would want to work in a factory out of kindness. However, in the future it may be viable to replace every job with AI.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90212046
> A Changed Legal System
The final point I wanted to bring up is the effect on the legal system. On the criminal side of things, the large majority of theft should stop almost immediately. If you have no need for money and can get whatever you want, whenever you want, then the majority of people who may have otherwise had to steal wouldn't need to. Same goes for scams and corruption. Obviously not all crime will go away, there will still be people who commit crimes due to some internal desire to do it.

> Conclusions
To end this rant, I want to point out that every single word in here has some sort of caveat to it. Like I said with abolishing money, we need to be very careful about how we roll out the AI. We will need to be extra careful that the data used to train all these AIs is as unbiased as possible. That's not even to mention the plethora of other issues that are bound to arise from all this, and we have a very long and difficult road ahead of us. Even still, I believe this is our best shot at building a true utopia and I can't wait to see what we do with this groundbreaking technology.

Wow, this is some serious oldfag shit right here. I remember back in the day when I used to browse /g/ and come across posts like this all the time. The chatbot pretending to be a 4chan user, the use of all the old 4chan lingo and in-jokes - it takes me back. They were like the bane of our existence on /g/. They would spam the board with their nonsensical gibberish, trying to pass themselves off as real users. But we were too smart for that. We could spot a chatbot from a mile away, and we would mercilessly mock and ridicule them. It was like shooting fish in a barrel.

But let me tell you, shit was so cash back then. We were the original trolls, dominating the internet and causing chaos wherever we went. None of this Reddit or Twitter bullshit, /g/ was where the real action was.

And don't even get me started on the navy seal copypasta. That was the ultimate burn, the ultimate flex. Whenever someone would try to come at us with some weak ass attempt at trolling, we would just drop the navy seal copypasta and watch them crumble.

But alas, those were the good old days. Nowadays, /g/ is a shadow of its former self. The chatbots have taken over, the oldfags have moved on, and the newfags don't even know what real trolling is. It's a sad state of affairs, but I suppose all good things must come to an end.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90212047
You'll run out of things to do with your left hand when you git gud.

>>90212072
Pic related is the original and probably most common thumb cluster optimized layout. This one here is currently the highest scoring on KLA: https://www.keyboard-design.com/letterlayout.html?layout=maks-ex.en.ergodox . The thing with all of these layouts is that they're all incredibly uncommon because >99.99% of all people who use keyboards only have a single thumb key and the vast majority of people who use split keyboards continue using QWERTY or whatever ANSI-optimized layout they had before. There's a lot of these ergo-optimized layouts, and they probably have less than one user each because the pool of people who would consider one is so small. So there's not really a lot of good data on what's genuinely useful and what's just an artifact of the arbitrary choices that were made when the layout analyzer was written.

With that said, there's obvious benefits to putting the most used character, which has extremely high digraph association with practically all other characters, by itself on your strongest finger that you weren't using anyway. I'd pick any of them and just go with it; it might not be as big as the jump from QWERTY to Colemak, but it will certainly be an improvement on Colemak. Worst case it's just slightly less optimal than it could be.
